title: Fix armor formula to include monster level
description: Current armor formula uses armor / (armor + 100) which ignores monster level. GDD specifies: Damage Reduction % = Armor / (Armor + K) where K = 100 + (10 * Monster Level). This makes armor less effective against higher-level monsters, adding a meaningful scaling pressure.
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Clear task spec with exact line numbers and formula made implementation straightforward
- What was unclear: Whether enemy projectiles should carry level info from their source enemy; defaulted to level 1 for now since projectile entities don't have a level property
close_reason: Armor formula now scales with monster level per GDD: armor / (armor + 100 + 10 * monsterLevel)

title: Wire map tier bonus into monster scaling
description: Map tier bonus (mapTierBonus) is always 0 in MonsterScaling.ts. The MapItem's tier value needs to be passed through to the scaling config so higher-tier maps actually produce tougher monsters. Per GDD formula: Monster Level = max(Map Base Level, Player Level - 2) + Map Tier Bonus.
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Clear task description with exact file paths and line numbers made this straightforward to implement.
- What was unclear: Nothing -- the implementation steps were well-defined.
close_reason: Map tier bonus now wired into monster scaling. MapDevice tracks activeTierBonus from mapItem.tier, WaveSystem and EnemySpawner use getActiveTierBonus() instead of DEFAULT_SCALING_CONFIG.

title: Town visual overhaul: bazaar-style visualizer with tent NPCs and reactive ambient effects
description:
Replace the plain 20x15 walled rectangle town with a living bazaar scene that reacts to audio. Each NPC gets a colored tent/canopy instead of a floating shape. Ambient effects (lanterns, particles, sky glow) pulse with the music via an AnalyserNode tap on ChipPlayer.

The visual concept is based on the "Bazaar of the Midnight Sun" music video renderer from ~/projects/htmlstyleguides/music/visualizer/bazaar-of-the-midnight-sun-video.html — but adapted to work as a generic audio-reactive visualizer (not tied to one song) rendered in PixiJS on the world layer.
design:
## Architecture

### 1. Audio Energy Tap (ChipPlayer change)
Add an AnalyserNode to `src/audio/ChipPlayer.ts` between masterGain and destination:
- `getEnergy(): number` — returns 0-1 based on frequency data (average of low-mid bins)
- Expose via `src/audio/MusicPlayer.ts` as `musicPlayer.getEnergy()`
- Tiny change: ~15 lines in ChipPlayer, ~5 in MusicPlayer

### 2. Town Visualizer (`src/map/TownVisualizer.ts` — new file)
Draws the bazaar scene on the world layer using PixiJS Graphics each frame. Key elements from the Bazaar video to port:

**Sky/Background** (drawn on worldLayer behind tiles):
- Gradient sky: deep purple top → dusky rose mid → amber horizon
- Palette: SKY_TOP=[25,12,50], SKY_MID=[60,20,40], SKY_BOT=[200,100,30]
- Sun at horizon with radial glow, pulsing with audio energy
- Stars (small dots with twinkle) in upper sky area
- Heat haze lines near horizon

**NPC Tents/Stalls** (replace plain NPC shapes):
- 5 colored fabric canopies at NPC positions, matching NPC colors:
  - Vendor (green 0x44cc44) → green tent canopy
  - Salvage (orange 0xee8833) → orange tent
  - Skill Trainer (blue 0x4488ff) → blue tent
  - Map Device (purple 0xaa44dd) → purple tent
  - Stash (grey 0xdddddd) → white/grey tent
- Each tent: two posts + curved canopy (quadraticCurveTo) + counter + goods on counter
- Canopy stripe pattern for visual interest
- Keep NPC label text above tent

**Lanterns** (ambient):
- 10-14 lanterns at varying heights, swinging on ropes
- Glow radius pulses with audio energy
- Lantern colors: amber, orange, red, gold
- Flicker effect on beat pulses

**Particles** (dust/spice motes):
- ~80-120 small circles drifting upward
- Speed and density scales with energy
- Colors from warm palette (amber, orange, gold)

**How energy drives visuals:**
- `energy > 0.3`: lantern glow radius increases, particles move faster
- `energy > 0.5`: sun ray alpha increases, subtle amber flash
- Beat detection (energy spike): lanterns flicker brighter, brief flash overlay
- Always subtle — town should feel warm and alive, not frantic

### 3. Town Map Changes
- Expand `TownMap.ts` from 20x15 to ~30x20 tiles to give tents room
- Place tent positions to match NPC tile offsets (currently: Vendor -5/-2, Salvage -5/+2, Trainer 0/-3, MapDevice +5/-2, Stash +5/+2)
- May need to widen NPC spacing slightly

### 4. NPC.ts Changes
- Replace simple shape drawing with tent rendering (or delegate to TownVisualizer)
- Keep the existing click detection system (checkNPCClick with 40px radius)
- NPC shape still drawn small on top of tent as the "merchant" figure
- Label stays above

### 5. Integration in Game.ts
- In the frame update, when `isInTown()`, call `townVisualizer.update(dt, musicPlayer.getEnergy())`
- TownVisualizer manages its own Graphics objects on worldLayer

## Reference Files

**Source inspiration** (read these first):
- `~/projects/htmlstyleguides/music/visualizer/bazaar-of-the-midnight-sun-video.html` — full Canvas2D renderer with all drawing functions (drawSky, drawSun, drawStall, drawLantern, drawParticles, drawMerchant, etc.)
- `~/projects/htmlstyleguides/music/audio-tracker/songs/bazaar-of-the-midnight-sun.json` — song JSON (116 BPM, Nordic Fiddle + Hardingfele + Drone Bass + Frame Drum + Aurora Pad)

**Pixeloot files to modify:**
- `src/audio/ChipPlayer.ts` — add AnalyserNode, getEnergy()
- `src/audio/MusicPlayer.ts` — expose getEnergy()
- `src/map/TownMap.ts` — expand town size, adjust spawn
- `src/entities/NPC.ts` — tent visuals replacing plain shapes
- `src/core/TownManager.ts` — init/cleanup TownVisualizer
- `src/Game.ts` — call TownVisualizer.update() in frame loop when in town

**Key existing patterns:**
- Town uses `game.worldLayer` for grid/tiles, `game.entityLayer` for NPCs
- Camera centers on player by offsetting worldLayer/entityLayer/effectLayer
- hudLayer is screen-space (unaffected by camera)
- All colors use UITheme.ts constants where applicable
- NPC click detection uses world coordinates via `screenToWorld()`

## Bazaar Video Key Drawing Functions to Port

From the video renderer, these are the main draw functions and their PixiJS equivalents:

1. `drawSky()` → PixiJS Graphics with linear gradient fill
2. `drawSun()` → Graphics circle + radial gradient (may need a sprite/filter for glow)
3. `drawStall()` → Graphics paths for posts, quadraticCurveTo for canopy, rects for counter
4. `drawLantern()` → Graphics circle for body + glow, line for rope, position oscillates with sin()
5. `drawParticles()` → Small Graphics circles repositioned each frame
6. `drawStars()` → Tiny Graphics circles with alpha oscillation
7. `drawHeatHaze()` → Optional, Graphics lines with sin() offset

Note: Canvas2D gradients (createLinearGradient/createRadialGradient) don't have direct PixiJS Graphics equivalents. Options:
- Use PixiJS FillGradient for linear gradients
- Use a small generated texture for radial glow effects
- Or render sky/sun to a separate canvas and use as a Sprite texture
acceptance_criteria:
- Town shows tent canopies at each NPC position with matching colors
- Ambient lanterns swing and flicker, particles drift
- All effects react to audio energy from ChipPlayer (brighter/faster when music is louder)
- Works with any track (town, combat, etc.) — not hardcoded to one song
- Existing NPC click interaction unchanged
- No performance regression (maintain 60fps)
- npm run build passes
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Clean separation — TownVisualizer as its own class on worldLayer, tent rendering on entityLayer, energy tap via AnalyserNode inserted between masterGain and destination. Expanding town from 20x15 to 30x20 tiles gave tents room.
- What was unclear: Nothing major. The task spec was detailed and the codebase patterns were consistent.
close_reason: Implemented bazaar-style town visualizer with audio-reactive effects: gradient sky, sun with glow, tent canopies at NPC positions, swinging lanterns, drifting particles, twinkling stars. Added AnalyserNode energy tap to ChipPlayer. Expanded town to 30x20 tiles. Build passes.

title: Add stat respec for gold
description: Currently there is no way to undo stat point allocation. GDD says respec should be available at a gold cost. Options: add a Respec button to the stat panel (Tab), or add it as an NPC interaction in town. Should reset all stat points and refund them for re-spending. Gold cost could scale with level.
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Clean integration into existing StatPanel pattern -- reused applyStatEffects, same button styling conventions, and the existing ECS query pattern extended with 'gold'.
- What was unclear: Whether floating text should appear in world space or panel space -- chose panel-local feedback text since the player is interacting with UI, not the game world.
close_reason: Stat respec available in stat panel for gold. Respec button added below computed stats, costs level*50 gold, refunds all allocated points, grayed out when no stats allocated or insufficient gold, with feedback text.

title: Implement remaining map modifiers (Fire Enchanted, Volatile, Iron Skin, Empowered Boss)
description: 4 of 7 map modifiers are defined in the pool and displayed in the UI but have no gameplay effect. Need to implement: (1) Fire Enchanted - enemies apply Burn status on hit, (2) Volatile - enemies explode on death dealing AoE damage, (3) Iron Skin - enemies resist first hit (shield/absorb), (4) Empowered Boss - boss gets +2 extra phases. Only hp_boost, speed_boost, and extra_swarm currently work.
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: The codebase already had partial scaffolding for 3 of 4 modifiers (iron skin check in CollisionSystem, fire enchanted on contact, volatile with damage). This made it straightforward to fill in the gaps.
- What was unclear: The volatile modifier's original implementation used enemy.damage * 0.5 which could be 0 for snipers; switching to 15% max HP is more consistent. The empowered boss phase scaling needed careful interpolation to feel smooth across 5 phases instead of just 3.
close_reason: All 7 map modifiers now have runtime effects. Implemented: (1) Fire Enchanted - enemies apply Burn on contact AND projectile hits, (2) Volatile - 15% max HP AoE explosion on death with orange particle burst, (3) Iron Skin - first hit absorbed (0 damage) with grey number, (4) Empowered Boss - 5 phases (0.8/0.6/0.4/0.2 thresholds) with escalating attack speed and burst count.
